JohnCartwright
Royal Navy officer Major in the Nottinghamshire militia
Marnham, Nottinghamshire, England
London
political reformer military Supported the aims of the American Revolution and radical and reformist causes in Great Britain. Corresponded with Thomas Jefferson. Wrote a pamphlet in 1776 advocating annual parliaments, the secret ballot, and universal manhood suffrage. Founder of the Society for Constutional Information, which developed into the London Corresponding Society. In 1794, witness at the "Treason Trials" supporting Horne Took, Thelwall, and Hardy. Also associated with Sir Francis Burdett, William Cobbett, and Francis Place. In 1812, founded the Hampden Clubs, political clubs designed to bring together like-minded middle-class reformers and working-class radicals. Supporter of Thomas Wooler and the Black Dwarf. The Life and Correspondence of Major Cartwright was published in 1826.
WilliamBeecheySir William Beechey Member of the Royal Academy
Burford, Oxfordshire
London
artistOfficial portrait painter to Queen Charlotte, he painted many members of the royal family as well as celebrated figures such as Sarah Siddons and Lord Nelson. He specialized in smaller scale full-length portraits.

James Francis Edward
St. James Palace, England
Rome, Italy
Prince of Wales the Pretender the old Pretender
St. James Palace, England
Son of the deposed James II of England and Ireland and James VII of Scotland. As such, he claimed the English, Scottish and Irish thrones (as James III of England and Ireland and James VIII of Scotland) after the death of his father in 1701. Scottish supporters started "The 'Fifteen" Jacobite rising in Scotland in 1715, aimed at putting him on the British throne, but the uprising failed. After his death, the right to the Stuart succession was claimed by his son Charles Edward Stuart.
JohnBellamy Author of The Holy Bible newly translated from the original Hebrew: with notes critical and explanatory, published by subscription in 1818. translator
Mr. MarriottIn a letter of 1819-04-08, Mitford inquires of Elford whether this Mr. Marriott is the same as the one mentioned in Scott's Marmion, the Rev. John Marriott, A.M. We do not have Elford's reply. Exact identity unknown. Needs further research.

London, England literary Second son of John Soane, architect. He wrote numerous melodramas for the stage between 1817 and 1850. He translated works from the French, German, and Italian, including de la Motte's story Undine which he translated into prose in 1818 and then turned into a play by 1821.

King of the West Saxons and of the Anglo-Saxons. In addition to his military victories, including the defeat of the Danes at the Battle of Edington, Alfred is known as a wise governmental administrator and proponent of learning and literacy. Source: DNB

Oliver Cromwell
Cromwell Oliver
Huntingdon
Whitehall, London
politician British politician who gained prominence as a military general during the the English Civil War, leading the New Model Army who supported Parliament against the monarchy, under Charles I. Cromwell became the First Protectorate of England, Scotland, and Ireland from 1653 until his death in 1658. At the time MRM was writign this letter and thorughout the 19th century, Cromwell's reputation was on an upswing. The trend was towards viewing him as a man guided by devout faith in God, a desire to provide for his country, and a desire to purify the Protestantism in his country.
Henry Peter Brougham 1st Baron Brougham and Vaux Lord Chancellor legal political Scottish
One of the founders of the Edinburgh Review. Practiced law in Edinburgh and London. Whig reformer and member of Parliament; known for educational and legal reforms. Chief legal advisor to Queen Caroline and defended her in 1820.
Mahomet French spelling of Muhammad, used by Mitford to refer to the prophet. Elsewhere, Mitford refers to "Mahound and Termagaunte" as stereotypically violent Islamic gods.

FrancisCowsladeFrank CowslageAs Coles notes, Francis or "Frank" Cowslade was one of the publishers of the Reading Mercury newspaper (Coles # 16, p.95, note 11).
HenryHarrisAt the time of Foscari's composition, Henry Harris was manager of Covent Garden Theatre. He took over the management from October 1820, following the death of his father, Thomas Harris, and the transfer by John Kemble of his one-sixth share to his younger brother Charles. Source: 'Covent Garden Theatre and the Royal Opera House: Management.' Survey of London: Volume 35, the theatre Royal, Drury Lane, and the Royal Opera House, Covent Garden. Ed. F. H. W. Shepard. London: London County Council, 1970. 71-85. British History Online. Web. 9 June 2015. .

Johnson Mr. Johnson the Junius of Marlow Timothy Trueman
Friend who leaves his collection of political books to Northmore upon his death in 1821. Mitford helps his sister, Miss Johnson, sort out the books that are part of the estate, according to her letter of 1 July 1821. Lived at Seymour Court before his death. Mitford reports meeting Mr. Johnson and Mr. Northmore for the first time in March 1819 in a letter to Elford. She describes him as "one of those delightful old men that render age so charming--mild playful kind & wise--talking just as Isaac Walton would have talked if we were to [have] gone out fishing with him." More research needed.
JohnsonMiss JohnsonFriend of Mitford's. Unmarried sister of Miss Johnson. Mitford helps her sort out the books that are part of her brother's estate, according to her letter of 1 July 1821. More research needed..
John Opie painted Dr. Richard Valpy's portrait. See
ValpyMaryMiss Valpy1797Eldest daughter of Dr. Valpy. More research needed.
ValpyPenelopeArabella1802Eldest daughter of Dr. Valpy. More research needed.
NewmanButler to Dr. Valpy in 1821 and likely earlier. Mitford calls him "the old butler" in a her letter of 1 July 1821. More research needed.
JamesEmilySister to Miss James and Susan James and cared for pupils with her. More research needed.
JamesSusanSister to Miss James and Emily James. Mitford reports that she has taked a position as a governess in 1819. Nicknamed "Susy." More research needed.
JamesMrs. JamesMother of Miss James, Susan James, and Emily James. Mitford reports that she has taken a position as a governess in 1819. Nicknamed "Susy." More research needed.
JohnWebb Unidentified. More research needed. Possibly "Uncle John," uncle to Eliza and Mary Webb and brother to James Webb. He is unlikely to be Aunt Mary's husband, since the elder Mary Webb was unmarried.
KateWheeler Miss Wheeler Friend of Miss James. Mitford refers to her as providing home remedies and advice. See 29 January 1821 letter to Mary Webb. More research needed.
Mr. Crowther
The "dandy" Mitford pokes fun at in her letters of January 9 and 10, 1819. Possibly husband to Isabelle Crowther. According to Coles, forename may be Phillip; Coles is not completely confident that the "dandy" Mr. Crowther and Mr. [Phillip?] Crowther are the same person. The second Mr. Crowther is a correspondent of Mitford's, whom she writes to at Whitley cottage, near Reading. He may also have resided at Westbury on Trim near Bristol. William Coles is uncertain of whether Crowtheris the same Phillip Crowthermentioned in Mitford's Diary. Source: William Coles, Letter to Needham, 10 November 1957, NeedhamPapers, Reading Central Library.
Mariede Rabutin-Chantal literary An aristocrat otherwise known as Marquise de Sevigne, she is famous in French literature for her letter-writing to her daughter.
MorrisBirkbeck Author of Notes on a Journey in America and Letters from Illinois.
ThomasLove Peacock literary Poet, essayist, satiric novelist. Most famous novels were published between 1815 and 1822.
Henry Bradshaw Fearon London surgeon who wrote Sketches of America. A Narrative of a Journey of Five Thousand Miles through the Eastern and Western States of America
Geoffrey Chaucer literary Born in London circa 1340. Wrote "The Canterbury Tales", "The Legend of Good Women", "Roman de la Rose", and other works.
Mary Brunton literary Contemporary of Jane Austen's. Called "The Forgotten Scottish Novelist."
AlexanderBrunton Husband of Mary Brunton; he was a clergyman from Edinburgh.

William Bewick
William Bewick
Danlington, county Durham
Haughton-le-Skerne, county Durham
portrait and history painter He was the pupil of Benjamin Robert Haydon with whom he remained for about three years. At Haydon's studio he met many famous men of the day, including Wordsworth, Hazlitt, and Keats. He worked hard under Haydon's influence, and besides working in his master's studio attended the Royal Academy Schools, and the dissecting teams of the physiologist and surgeon Sir Charles Bell. When he died, he was a substantial property owner in the village. His portrait work is extensively represented in the National Portrait Gallery and the British Museum, London, and the Scottish National Portrait Gallery, Edinburgh. Bewick was not a member of the family of Thomas Bewick, the engraver, as is sometimes believed.
Edward Chatfield
Edward Chatfield
66 Judd Street Brunswick Square, London
painter and author Chatfield was a pupil at an early age, by 1816, along with William Bewick, of Benjamin Robert Haydon who was to have an overmastering influence on his life. Under Haydon's teaching he went through a full course of practical anatomy. He began his artistic career with some portrait studies. In 1821 he started upon his first ambitious picture, The Death of Moses in Sight of the Promised Land. This was exhibited in January 1823 at the British Institution and was well received by the public, and gained warm commendation by Haydon. In June 1823 Haydon was arrested for debt, and his effects sold. Some of his pupils had put their names to bills at his request, and suffered considerable pecuniary loss. Chatfield was among the number, but was fortunately able to provide the amount due (£210), and, though impoverished, did not begrudge Haydon the loss and remained loyal to his master, whose instruction had always been given gratis. Thrown on his own resources, Chatfield was compelled to supplement his slender income by portrait painting. Among his sitters were several members of the Russell family (the duke of Bedford's family).
Laetitia Macready
Macready Laetitia
William Charles Macready's sister who live with him and his wife throughout their married life.
Christopher Magnay Lord Mayor of London Lord Mayor of London from 1821 to 1822.
Hall Waldron Elford Elizabeth
Mrs. Elford Elizabeth is the second wife of Sir William Elford; they married four years after the death of Mrs. Mary Elford on July 5, 1821. The ODNB's entry on Sir William Elford incorrectly gives her name as Elizabeth Walrond (née Hall), as parish records of 1822 accord with the spelling in Mitford's letters, and describe Elizabeth Hall Waldron as the heiress of an estate in Devonshire, formerly married to a Colonel Waldron. Source: 'Parishes: Pancras Week - Plymouth', Magna Britannia: volume 6: Devonshire (1822), pp. 381-408.
Elford Davies Mary
Mrs. Elford
Mary was the first wife of Sir William Elford; they married on January 20, 1776. (ODNB)
Sir William Elford
Elford William Sir baronet
Kingsbridge, Devon
Totnes
According to L'Estrange, Elford was a friend of Mitford's father, and Mitford met him for the first time in the spring of 1810 when he was nearing the age of 64. "He was a fellow of the Royal and Linnaean Societies, and recorder of Plymouth, which borough he also represented in Parliament for many years. Mr. Pitt had created him a baronet in 1800." [L'Estrange vol. 1 of 3, pp. 104-105]
JohnathanElford Mr. Elford
Only son of Sir William Elford and Mary Davies Elford; married Charlotte WynneCharlotte Wynne on May 10, 1810. Was briefly a Member of Parliament.
GraceChardElford Miss Elford
Only daughter of Sir William Elford and Mary Davies Elford; unmarried. Birthdate needs additional research.
ElizabethElfordAdams Miss Elford
Only daughter of Sir William Elford and Elizabeth Hall Waldron Elford. Married General Sir George Pownoll Adams, RCH.
CharlotteWynneElford Mrs. Elford Married Johnathon Elford on May 10, 1810.
Maria Foote
Stanhope Foote Maria
Plymouth
Whitehall, London
actress a well known English theater actress. She was the daughter of Samuel Foote. She played Alfonso, the King of Sicily in Julian. She performed at Drury Lane from 1814-1825 and then began to perform at Covent Garden in 1826.
Mary Anne HansonPortsmouthLady PortsmouthCountess of PortsmouthMary Ann Hanson was the daughter of solicitor John Hanson. She was the second wife of John Charles Walopp, 3rd Earl of Portsmouth, until their marriage was annulled in 1823 on the grounds of the Earl's insanity.
JohnHanson. John Hanson was solicitor for Byron as well as solicitor and trustee for John Charles Walopp, 3rd Earl of Portsmouth. In 1814 his daughter Mary Anne married Lord Portsmouth; the marriage was later annulled.
John Charles Walopp Portsmouth 3rd Earl of Portsmouth Lord Portsmouth Viscount Lymington
Legally declared insane since 1809 in a well-publicized series of court hearings in 1823. After this case, his second marriage to Mary Anne Hanson, the daughter of his solicitor and trustee, was annulled. They married on 7 March 1814.

artist Allan was a painter. In 1838 he was appointed president of the Royal Scottish Academy. In 1841 he became the queen's limner in Scotland and was knighted (ODNB). Mitford mentions his painting A Broken Fiddle in her letter to Elford, 1821-11-21

diplomatist author John Hookham Frere, diplomat and author, was a founder of the Quarterly Review and is known for his humorous poetry and translations of Aristophanes and the poet Theognis. He wrote under the name "Whistlecraft." (Source: ODNB)
Mrs. Dobbs
Dobbs
An associate of both Mitford and Miss James, presumably older than either. Possibly housekeeper to the James sisters. Need further research.
Webb James 11 January 1822 brewer Wokingham
Prominent brewer in the Wokinghambrewing industry, father of Eliza and Mary Webb, and brother of another Mary Webb. Francis Needham suggested that he was the original of the "gentleman" in the Our Villagesketch "Aunt Martha". Source: Francis Needham, Letter to William Roberts, 16 June 1953. Needham Papers, Reading Central Library.
Webb Mary 15 April 1796
Sister of Eliza Webb, daughter of , and niece of . Noted by Needham, referencing the Berkshire Directory, to be living on Broad Street.
Webb Mary
Friend of Mitford. Sister of James Webb and aunt of Eliza and Mary Webb. Francis Needhamsuggests that she was the basis for the character of Aunt Martha in the Our Villagestory of that title. Source: Francis Needham, Letter to William Roberts, 16 June 1953. Needham Papers, Reading Central Library.

Frankland
A friend of Mrs. Mitford. Needs further research.

playwright architect Sir John Vanbrugh was a noted architect and successful playwright who wrote original comedies and adapted others. His The City Wives' Confederacy was first staged in 1705. (Source: ODNB)

scholar President of Magdalen College, Oxford University
Harness Mary Sister of William Harness; she lived with her brother.
William Lane Lane William
Publisher William Lane pioneered the circulating library, and was the founder of the Minerva Press, a major publisher of Gothic novels and other popular fiction.
HenryKempRichardson Coles says this is Henry Kemp Richardson of Reading, see p.471, note 5. One of the 1827 sonnets is address to a Henry Richardson. Needs further research.
Robinson Henry Coles says Mitford is probably correct that this is Henry Crabbe Robinson, although the record only shows that the attorney was Mr. Robinson. See p. 525, note 13. Needs additional research.
Mr. Vines Coles says this is the son of Edward Vines, possibly named Jacob, see p. 524, note 9. Needs additional research.
John Wilson wrote under the pseudonym Christopher North for Blackwood's Magazine.
Mr. Swan"On the 17th, convicted of bribery at an election for the borough of Penrhyn, in Cornwall, was sentenced to be confined in the King's Bench Prison for one year." See Edinburgh Magazine 5 (July-Dec. 1819): 568.

Sligo, Ireland
London literary barrister judge
CharlesMaturin
clergy literary
Dickinson girl Mr. and Mrs. Charles Dickinson's young daughter Frances
Betsy Broughton Local beauty, engaged to Mr. Hawley through Mrs. Dickinson's matchmaking.
Mr. Hawley Descendant of General Hawley, engaged to Betsy Broughton through Mrs. Dickinson's matchmaking.
General HawleyPossibly Lieutenant General Henry Hawley (c. 1679-24 March 1759), British army officer who served during the War of Spanish Succession as well as the Jacobite Rebellion.
Queen Anne 6 Feb. 1665 1 Aug. 1714 Queen of England, Scotland, and Ireland on 8 March 1702. In 1707, after the Acts of Union uniting England and Scotland into Great Britain, she reigned as Queen of Great Britain and Ireland.
